description: First two confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Hong Kong announced between the late hours of the 22nd and early hours of the 23rd.
Hong Kong raises response level to virus outbreak to ’emergency’ – the highest warning tier, suspends school classes, and cancels marathon

Enhanced measures to stop the novel coronavirus’ spread announced. High-speed rail service between Hong Kong and mainland China is suspended. All cross-border ferry services, flights and cross-border bus services from mainland China are reduced by 50%. Half of the city’s border checkpoints are closed.
Facilities overseen by the Leisure and Cultural Services Department (LCSD), including all public museums, libraries and sports centres and venues, closed.
6,500 medical staff to go on strike to pressure the government to close its border with China
Hong Kong reports first death from COVID-19
Hong Kong unveils virus quarantine plans, with jail for dodgers.

Economic relief in the form of: $10,000 cash payout to Hong Kong permanent residents aged 18 or above, reduction of salaries tax under personal assessment for 2019-20 assessment year by 100%, subject to ceiling of $20,000, waiving of rates for domestic properties for four quarters of 2020-21, subject to a $1,500 ceiling per quarter, and other economic plans
Cheung Chau Bun Festival cancelled
HKUST Develops New Smart Anti-Microbial Coating in the combat of COVID-19 in public places like schools, shopping malls and school buses.

Hong Kong closes its border to all incoming non-residents arriving from overseas. Transiting through Hong Kong is no longer allowed either. All returning residents, regardless of point of departure, are subject to the Compulsory Quarantine Order, which required all to stay at a reported quarantine premise (either home or hotel) for 14 days.
Hong Kong bans public gatherings of more than four people. Restaurants required to operate at half their capacity and to set tables at least 1.5 meters apart.
Karaokes, night clubs and mahjong parlours to close from 3pm for 14 days
All pubs and bars ordered to close for 14 days.
Social distancing rules extended by 14 days.
Hong Kong Public Libraries has a partial reopening of some of its locations.
Hong Kong to relax business restrictions with gathering limit upped to 8 people
Schools resume classes in stages from 27 May, starting with secondary schools and moving progressively to younger ages.
Hong Kong extends social-distancing curbs including gathering ban.
Ocean park reopens, with others like Disneyland, trade fairs, and conventions set to open soon after.
Public gatherings of up to 50 people allowed.
Following an increase in COVID-19 cases in July, gathering restrictions will be tightened from 50 people to a maximum of 4 people.

Government announces new measures hoping to slow the spread: civil servants are to work from home and only emergency and essential public services will remain open; eat-in restaurants will be banned from 6pm to 5am, and mask-wearing in indoor public places is henceforth mandatory.

Secretary for Food and Health Sophia Chan admits there was “empirical evidence”  that quarantine exemption policies for over 30 groups of inbound travellers – including cross-boundary goods vehicle drivers, aircraft crew members, government officials on duty, and numerous company executives – had contributed to the recent increase in coronavirus cases.
Public gatherings limitted to two people; eating-in at restaurants banned; and making the wearing of face masks compulsory in all public places.
U-turn on eating-in at restaurants ban after 48 hours
China sends first Covid-19 medical testing team to Hong Kong.
Hong Kong to offer free Covid-19 tests to all residents
Hong Kong to open gyms and ease some restrictions as city records lowest daily cases in nearly 2 months. Restaurant dining hours will also be extended from 9 pm to 10 pm.
Gathering limit to rise to 4, most sports facilities to reopen.
Hong Kong bars, pools, theme parks and clubs to reopen but beaches to stay closed.
Hong Kong to extend social distancing measures to National Day amid online calls for protest.

Number of people allowed to sit together at restaurants will increase to six, four people will be permitted to be seated together at bars. Dining facilities will be permitted to remain open until 02:00 (local time). Entertainment businesses, including bars, amusement parks, swimming pools, and karaoke lounges, will be permitted to operate at 75 percent capacity with social distancing measures and hygiene measures.
Public beaches reopen with social distancing regulations continuing, including the wearing of face masks and limits on group gatherings.
Applications open for Return2hk - Travel Scheme for Hong Kong Residents returning from Guangdong Province or Macao without being subject to quarantine under the Compulsory Quarantine.
Elderly, care home staff, and taxi drivers prioritised for undergoing mandatory COVID-19 testing, including those with symptoms.
Hong Kong-Singapore 'travel bubble' is postponed amid Covid-19 spike
Hong Kong bars and nightclubs to close again after surge in infections.

Group gatherings limited to 2, eateries to close 10pm, new hotline for rule-breakers, karaoke lounges, amusement arcades, games rooms and concert halls are to close entirely. All civil servants will undergo work from home arrangements depending on each department’s operational needs. Only necessary and emergency personnel will need to commute to work.

Covid-19 specimen collection packs from vending machines set up inside ten MTR stations including: Ngau Tau Kok, Kwai Fong, North Point, Tiu Keng Leng, Wong Chuk Hang, Tai Wai, Tai Po Market, Kowloon and Tsing Yi.
Partial lockdowns can now be enforced in Covid-hit locations until mass tests can be conducted there.
Restaurants close for dine-in customers at 6 pm for two weeks. Gyms, beauty parlours and massage parlours shut down for the same period.
Penalties for violating coronavirus social-distancing rules increase from HK$2,000 to HK$5,000

New genetic variant of COVID-19 detected in two students who returned to Hong Kong from the United Kingdom. This prompted the government to implement a 21-day quarantine rule for those coming back from the UK.

Hong Kong extends the compulsory quarantine in designated quarantine hotels to 21 days, for all arrivals having stayed outside China at any time during the past 21 days. This made Hong Kong have the longest hotel quarantine in the world.
Hong Kong imposes first lockdown in Covid-hit Jordan – 10,000 residents affected, 3,000 personnel deployed
Sudden evening lockdown in Yau Ma Tei yields one positive case after 330 people undergo compulsory testing.
Hong Kong imposes third overnight Covid-19 lockdown, no cases found after 400 tested.
Hong Kong exempts China’s Sinovac vaccine from medical journal requirement.
After 24,000 people had been tested during 25 lockdowns, and only four of them yielded positive cases Carrie Lam promises no lockdowns over Lunar New Year.

Gyms, beauty parlors, theme parks, and cinemas allowed to reopen. Eateries allowed to extend their dine-in service to 10:00 pm, with diners having to use the LeaveHomeSafe government app to check in. Gathering size increase from 2 to 4 people.
Hong Kong’s vaccination programme begins as three centres are switched to China-made vaccine
The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine was introduced for public use on 10 March.
Fears Hong Kong gym Covid outbreak could result in 50 cases; fourth suspected death after Sinovac jab
Hong Kong to open up Covid-19 vaccine programme to 30-59 year olds, domestic workers, and students aged over 16 who are in education overseas
Hong Kong suspends BioNTech Covid-19 vaccines ‘as precaution’ over defective packaging
Arrangements for designated flights from the United Kingdom (UK) to Hong Kong and the latest quarantine arrangements for arrivals from overseas low-risk specified places.
300,000 Pfizer-BioNTech shots land in city for vaccination relaunch.
Hong Kong suspends flights from India, Pakistan, and the Philippines for two weeks after the N501Y mutant COVID-19 strain was detected in Hong Kong.

Cross-boundary goods vehicle drivers who have received two vaccine doses for 14 days and received a message in the Yuekang Code system issued by Guangdong Province are not required to undergo a nucleic acid test once every day.
The Return2hk Scheme was extended from Guangdong and Macau to other Mainland provinces and municipalities.

The Government to roll out the Come2hk Scheme later this month, the scheme will enable non-Hong Kong residents, including Mainland people and expatriates who live and work in the Mainland, to come to Hong Kong without undergoing compulsory quarantine.
Education Bureau announces all kindergartens, primary, and secondary schools may fully resume face-to-face classes on a half-day basis from May 24.
